answers.author: Aaron Nix
answers.text:
Yes, we started and they continue the Farmer's Market at their Park and Ride facility in the City of Auburn, WA.  The City hired a temporary Farmer's Market Coordinator who worked through issues pertaining to booth costs and the tough one of ensuring that farmers that would consistently show up.  The Market has been running for several years and appears to be getting more popular as the years go by.  If I recall, the City utilizes its own insurance carrier for the event, but I'm not positive.  A good contact is Council Member Bill Peloza at bpeloza@auburnwa.gov as he is still there and was an original organizer of the event.
Regards,
Aaron Nix

answers.author: Patricia Greene
answers.text:
I would like to refer you to this link regarding a public private partnership where the management of the local farmer's market was bidded to vendors and then awarded to a local not for profit  http://www.greensboro-nc.gov/index.aspx?page=1121
Also, with regard to food trucks, I was able to find that a  business privilege license is required to operate  what is described as a push cart.  I am certain that since food is involved, the city has listed other requirements to obtain a license such as food establishment permit.
Hope this helps

author: [Anonymous]
text:
How does your City manage food truck events and/or farmer markets?  Since they are mobile, they do not qualify for conditional use permits.  Do you allow for operation on city property, such as parks, plazas, and/or other public lots?
Thanks for any and all responses.
title: Food Trucks and Special Events
